Administration of Justice - Overview

Study Framework

This section covers the practitioner's role in the administration of justice, focusing on court proceedings, client responsibility, and maintaining the integrity of the legal system.

Core Rule Categories

Rules 9-13: Court Proceedings

Scope: Conduct before Court, Client Responsibility, Conflicts, Witnesses, Court Respect

Core rules governing how lawyers conduct themselves in court proceedings, handle conflicts of interest, and interact with witnesses and the court.

Key Topics:

  • Rule 9: Conduct of Proceedings before Court
  • Rule 10: Responsibility for Client's Conduct
  • Rule 11: Conflict of Interest in Proceedings
  • Rule 12: Communications with Witnesses
  • Rule 13: Respect for Court

Rules 14, 15, 7: Criminal & Relationships

Scope: Criminal Defense, Prosecution, Lawyer Relationships

Specialized rules for criminal proceedings and professional relationships between lawyers, including courtesy, fairness, and communication protocols.

Key Topics:

  • Rule 14: Conducting Defence in Criminal Proceedings
  • Rule 15: Conducting the Prosecution
  • Rule 7: Relationship with Other Legal Practitioners

Rules 28-31, 8: Procedures & Conduct

Default Judgments, Allegations, Communications, General Conduct

Procedural rules for default judgments, making allegations against other lawyers, court communications, and general conduct with all persons.

Key Topics:

  • Rule 28: Entering Default Judgment
  • Rule 29: Allegations Against Another Legal Practitioner
  • Rule 30: Communication with Court
  • Rule 31: Communication with Another Legal Practitioner
  • Rule 8: Conduct in Relation to Other Persons

🎯 How to Use These Notes for Exam Success

Step 1: Understand the Structure
Each rule section contains: Full rule text, when it applies, what it means, case law examples, practical guidance, and exam application framework.
Step 2: Study by Scenario
Use the practical guidance sections to understand how rules apply in different situations. Look for the tree-like structures that show applicable rules, factors, and exceptions.
Step 3: Master Case Law
Each case includes: Situation, Facts, Ruling, Reasoning, What This Case Tells Us, and Key Reasoning. Use these to understand how courts apply the rules.
Step 4: Practice Application
Use the exam application framework to practice identifying situations, applicable rules, case law, and reaching conclusions.

Rule 9: Conduct of Proceedings before Court or Tribunal

Table of Contents

I. Foundation: Lawyers as Officers of the Supreme Court

Legal Basis

Section 82(1) of Legal Profession Act (LPA): Person duly admitted as an advocate and solicitor is an officer of the Supreme Court

Implication of Being an Officer of the Court

When this applies: This status applies to ALL lawyers admitted in Singapore

What this means: Officers of the Court have obligations to uphold the legal framework

Key Implications of Officer Status

Implication Source Practical Effect
Absolute duty to Court Public Trustee v By Products Traders Must serve public interest first
Override client interests Public Trustee v By Products Traders Client interests secondary to administration of justice
Duty of frankness and candor Public Trustee v By Products Traders Must assist Court properly
Cannot hide behind client instructions Prometheus Marine v King Personal responsibility for professional conduct

II. Rule 9: Overview and Principles

When Rule 9 Applies

Rule 9 applies when: A legal practitioner is conducting proceedings before any Court or tribunal

What this covers:

  • All court proceedings (civil, criminal, family, etc.)
  • Tribunal proceedings
  • Both preparatory work and actual proceedings
  • Communications with court staff, other lawyers, witnesses

Underlying Principles of Rule 9

Rule 9(1) establishes 8 fundamental principles:

Rule 9(1) Fundamental Principles

Principle Rule 9(1) Provision What This Means
1. Assist Justice (a) Must help in administration of justice
2. Act Honorably (a) Must act honorably in interests of justice
3. Uphold Integrity (b) Work must uphold Court/tribunal integrity
4. Contribute to Justice (b) Must contribute to attainment of justice
5. Be Truthful (c) Always truthful in communications
6. No False Evidence (d) Must not present false evidence/information
7. Maintain Fairness (e) Conduct must maintain fairness, integrity, efficiency
8. Comply with Law (f) Must comply with all applicable laws and PDs

III. Paramount Duty to the Court

THE PARAMOUNT DUTY PRINCIPLE

When this applies: In ALL proceedings before Court or tribunal

What this means: Lawyer's duty to Court overrides duty to client

CASE LAW FOUNDATION

Public Trustee and another v By Products Traders Pte Ltd

RULING: Lawyers have overriding duty to ensure administration of justice

FACTS: Case involved lawyers' conduct in court proceedings

REASONING:

  • By definition, "officer of the court" presupposes obligations to uphold legal framework
  • All solicitors have absolute and overriding duty first and foremost to the court
  • Must serve public interest by ensuring proper and efficient administration of justice
  • Can only pursue client's interests insofar as it doesn't compromise administration of justice

TABLE: IMPLICATIONS OF PARAMOUNT DUTY

Entry Client Instruction Lawyer's Duty Action Required
(i) Pursue every point to inflict damage Prevent waste of Court time Counsel client against unnecessary litigation
(ii) Put forward untenable position Decline to advance argument Refuse to present legally unsound arguments
(iii) Hide material facts Disclose all material facts Ensure Court has complete picture
(iv) Delay proceedings unnecessarily Assist in efficient disposal Avoid unnecessary adjournments

CASE LAW EXAMPLES - PARAMOUNT DUTY IN ACTION

(i) BOI v BOJ

SITUATION: Client wanted to pursue every point to inflict maximum damage

LAWYER'S DUTY: Must prevent client from wasting Court's time and resources

PRINCIPLE: Must counsel clients and apprise them of what is permissible

WHAT THIS CASE TELLS US: Lawyers must prevent clients from pursuing vindictive litigation strategies

KEY REASONING: Prevents clients from wasting the other party's and the court's time and resources

(ii) Prometheus Marine Pte Ltd v King, Ann Rita

SITUATION: Client instructed lawyer to put forward untenable position

LAWYER'S DUTY: Must decline to put forward the argument

PRINCIPLE: Cannot hide behind "following client's instructions" when questioned by Court

REASONING: Lawyer owes Court duty to consider evidence and ensure reasonable credible material before mounting arguments

WHAT THIS CASE TELLS US: Lawyers cannot escape personal responsibility by claiming they were "just following instructions"

KEY REASONING: Lawyer owes paramount duty to Court; must decline untenable arguments even if client instructs otherwise

Case Law Examples - Conduct Prejudicial to Justice

(iii) LSS v Ng Bock Hoh Dixon

Conduct: Prepared 2 false court judgments to deceive complainant's wife

Facts: Lawyer had prepared 2 false court judgements purportedly issued by Subordinate Courts to make complainant's wife believe that the complainant would be receiving money from his legal actions to alleviate the harassment by his wife

Ruling: Lawyer was struck off

Reasoning: Court documents were intended to facilitate the attainment of a just and fair decision but lawyer had used abused them demonstrating a lack of respect of the court process. Even though the false document wasn't a court document, it was an important accounting record relating to his law firm's account

What this case tells us: Abuse of court documents for personal gain is serious misconduct

Key reasoning: Court documents serve the administration of justice; abuse shows disrespect for court process

(iv) Zhou Tong v PP

Conduct: Unilaterally departed from procedural requirements; failed to inform court of uncontactable appellants

Facts: Lawyer had, without prior leave of Court, unilaterally decided to depart from the procedural requirement to file written skeletal arguments. Lawyer also knew at an earlier date that four of the appellants could not be contacted but had failed to inform the court and the PP of this until the appeal was heard

Ruling: Lawyer was strongly berated

Reasoning: Conduct was prejudicial to the efficient and orderly disposal of cases

What this case tells us: Negligence and procedural failures can be prejudicial to administration of justice

Key reasoning: Lawyers must follow procedural requirements and keep court informed of relevant developments

IV. Specific Duties Under Rule 9(2) - Prohibited Conduct

Overview of Rule 9(2)

When this applies: When conducting proceedings before court or tribunal on behalf of client

What this covers: 8 specific prohibitions (subsections a-h)

Rule 9(2) Prohibited Conducts

Subsection Prohibition Key Elements
9(2)(a) No misleading Cannot mislead court, staff, other lawyers, witnesses
9(2)(b) No fabrication Cannot fabricate facts or evidence
9(2)(c) No false statements Cannot include false statements in documents
9(2)(d) No personal opinions Cannot express personal opinion of client's conduct
9(2)(e) No bias from opinions Personal opinion cannot affect professional assessment
9(2)(f) No wrong law Cannot cite law out of context or misinterpret
9(2)(g) No concocted evidence Cannot concoct evidence or contrive facts
9(2)(h) No improper documents Cannot draft documents with unsupported statements

Detailed Analysis of Each Prohibition

(A) Duty Not to Mislead - Rule 9(2)(a)

When this applies: During any proceedings before court or tribunal

What this prohibits: Knowingly misleading or attempting to mislead:

  • The court or tribunal
  • Any staff of the court or tribunal
  • Any other legal practitioner
  • Any witness or person involved in proceedings
Types of Misleading Conduct
Type Description Example
Passive Concealing material facts Not disclosing adverse authority
Active Deliberately articulating untruths Making false representations
Combined Both passive and active Hiding facts AND making false statements
Case Law - Misleading Conduct
1. Re Ram Goswami

Conduct: Actively deceived Court about source of bail money

Facts: Solicitor argued that the bailor's bail money should not be forfeited for it represented his 15 year savings even though he knew that the bail money did not actually belong to the bailor

Ruling: Solicitor was suspended for 6 months

Reasoning: Deliberate deception of Court about source of bail money

What this case tells us: Active deception of Court about material facts is serious misconduct

Key reasoning: Lawyers must be truthful in all communications with Court

2. Dhanwant Singh

Conduct: Assisted client to avoid court attendance using fake medical certificates

Facts: Lawyer was convicted under s 174 read with s 109 PC, with a $3,000 fine. He was also struck off the rolls. It is the duty of every advocate and solicitor regardless of position to uphold the integrity of the judicial process. When an advocate and solicitor intentionally abets a client from delaying the judicial process, which very process it is his bounden duty to uphold, it shows an extreme defect of character

Ruling: Struck off the rolls

Reasoning: Duty to uphold integrity of judicial process; intentionally abetting client to delay judicial process shows extreme defect of character

What this case tells us: Assisting clients to avoid court proceedings through deception is serious misconduct

Key reasoning: Lawyers have bounden duty to uphold judicial process; assisting delay shows defect of character

V. Specific Duties Under Rule 9(3) - Required Conduct

Overview of Rule 9(3)

When this applies: When conducting proceedings before court or tribunal

What this covers: 2 specific positive duties (subsections a-b)

Rule 9(3) Required Conduct

Subsection Duty Key Elements
9(3)(a) Inform Court of authorities Must inform of every relevant decision and legislative provision
9(3)(b) Disclose required information Must disclose facts, evidence, information required by law

VI. Case Law Analysis

Comprehensive Case Law Summary

Major Cases by Category

Category Case Key Principle Ruling
Paramount Duty Public Trustee v By Products Traders Overriding duty to Court Foundation case
Paramount Duty Prometheus Marine v King Cannot hide behind client instructions Personal responsibility
Misleading Court Re Ram Goswami Active deception of Court 6 months suspension
Misleading Court Dhanwant Singh Assisting client to avoid court Struck off

VII. Practical Guidance Tables

Situation 1: Client gives false instructions

Applicable Rule: 9(2)(a), 9(2)(c)

Factors to Consider: Is information accurate? Are material facts disclosed? Is opposing authority mentioned?

Exceptions/Qualifications: Both passive and active misleading prohibited. Even draft documents can breach.

VIII. Exam Application Framework

Step-by-Step Approach for Exam Questions

Step 1: Identify the Situation

Ask yourself:

  • Is this a court/tribunal proceeding?
  • What type of conduct is involved?
  • Which party is the lawyer acting for?
  • What are the specific facts?

Rule 10: Responsibility for Client's Conduct

When this applies: In any communication with, or representation or submission to, the Court or tribunal

What this prohibits: Fabricating any fact or evidence

(C) Duty Not to Include False Statements - Rule 9(2)(c)

When this applies: In any document used for proceedings

What this prohibits: Including any statement of fact which lawyer knows to be false

LSS v Chung Ting Fai

CONDUCT: Drafting false affidavit to obtain extension of time to appeal

FACTS: Lawyer offered to resolve matter by appealing against the order on behalf of client. The time frame for filing appeal had lapsed and lawyer and assistant drafted affidavit to ask for extension for appeal. Affidavit placed blame for delay in filing appeal on the Client and was an inaccurate account of events leading up to decision to file appeal.

RULING: Lawyer was found to be in breach of then s83(2)(h) "guilty of misconduct unbefitting an advocate and solicitor" even though the false affidavit remained in draft form and had not been filed

REASONING: The fact that the false affidavit had not been filed was used as a mitigating factor in sentencing. Did not matter that the dishonest conduct arose from a misguided intention to assist the client

(D) Duty Not to Express Personal Opinion - Rule 9(2)(d)

When this applies: When conducting proceedings before court or tribunal

What this prohibits: Expressing personal opinion of the client's conduct

(E) Duty Not to Allow Personal Opinion to Affect Work - Rule 9(2)(e)

When this applies: When conducting proceedings before court or tribunal

What this prohibits: Allowing personal opinion to affect:

  • Professional assessment of facts or law
  • Duty to the court or tribunal

(F) Duty Not to Mislead with Wrong Law - Rule 9(2)(f)

When this applies: When conducting proceedings before court or tribunal

What this prohibits:

  • Knowingly or recklessly citing law out of context
  • Interpreting law in manner calculated to mislead court
  • Advancing submission which lawyer knows or ought reasonably to know is contrary to law

(G) Duty Not to Concoct Evidence - Rule 9(2)(g)

When this applies: When conducting proceedings before court or tribunal

What this prohibits: Concocting any evidence or contriving any fact (whether or not it assists client's case)

(H) Duty Not to Draft Improper Documents - Rule 9(2)(h)

When this applies: When drafting court documents

What this prohibits: Drafting any originating process, pleading, affidavit, witness statement or notice/grounds of appeal containing:

  • Unsupported statements (i): Statement not supported by client's instructions
  • Unarguable contentions (ii): Contention not reasonably and properly arguable
  • Unsupported fraud allegations (iii): Fraud allegation without clear instructions AND credible material
  • Inaccurate witness statements (iv): Statement witness wouldn't give if evidence given orally

Specific Duties Under Rule 9(3) - Required Conduct

Rule 9(3) establishes 2 specific positive duties (subsections a-b):

(A) Duty to Inform Court of Relevant Authorities - Rule 9(3)(a)

When this applies: When conducting proceedings before court or tribunal

What this requires: Inform court or tribunal of every relevant decision and legislative provision which lawyer is aware of, whether it:

  • Supports the lawyer's contentions, OR
  • Rebutts the lawyer's contentions

Important Principle

Concealing an authority which the solicitor is aware of is tantamount to misleading the Court

(B) Duty to Disclose Required Information - Rule 9(3)(b)

When this applies: When conducting proceedings before court or tribunal

What this requires: Disclose to court/tribunal and every other person involved in proceedings:

  • Every fact, item of evidence, item of information and other matters which lawyer is required by law to disclose
  • Any procedural irregularity of which lawyer is aware

Practical Guidance

Situation 1: Client gives false instructions

  • Applicable Rule: 9(2)(a), 9(2)(c)
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Is information accurate?
    • Are material facts disclosed?
    • Is opposing authority mentioned?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • Both passive and active misleading prohibited
    • Even draft documents can breach

Situation 2: Client wants to pursue weak case

  • Applicable Rule: 9(2)(h)(ii)
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Is contention reasonably arguable?
    • Are statements supported by instructions?
    • Is case legally sound?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • Must be "reasonably and properly arguable"
    • Cannot pursue frivolous claims

Situation 3: Client wants to allege fraud

  • Applicable Rule: 9(2)(h)(iii)
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Does lawyer have clear instructions?
    • Is there credible material for fraud?
    • Is fraud allegation supported?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • Need BOTH clear instructions AND credible material
    • Must establish prima facie case

Exam Application Framework

Step-by-Step Approach for Exam Questions

Step 1: Identify the Situation
Ask yourself: Is this a court/tribunal proceeding? What type of conduct is involved? Which party is the lawyer acting for? What are the specific facts?
Step 2: Identify Applicable Rules
Ask yourself: Does Rule 9 apply? Which specific subsection applies? Are there any exceptions? What is the paramount duty principle?
Step 3: Apply Case Law
Ask yourself: Which cases are most similar? What was the ruling in those cases? What was the reasoning? How does it apply to this situation?
Step 4: Reach Conclusion
Ask yourself: Is there a breach of Rule 9? What are the consequences? Are there any mitigating factors? What should the lawyer do?

Key Phrases for Exam Answers

• "As an officer of the Supreme Court under s82(1) LPA..." • "Rule 9(1) establishes the fundamental principle that..." • "The paramount duty to the Court requires..." • "In [Case Name], the Court held that..." • "The reasoning was that..." • "Applying this principle to the present case..." • "Therefore, there is/is not a breach of Rule 9..."

Case Law - Misleading Conduct

1. Re Ram Goswami

Conduct: Actively deceived Court about source of bail money

Facts: Solicitor argued that the bailor's bail money should not be forfeited for it represented his 15 year savings even though he knew that the bail money did not actually belong to the bailor

Ruling: Solicitor was suspended for 6 months

Reasoning: Deliberate deception of Court about source of bail money

What this case tells us: Active deception of Court about material facts is serious misconduct

2. Dhanwant Singh

Conduct: Assisted client to avoid court attendance using fake medical certificates

Facts: Lawyer was convicted under s 174 read with s 109 PC, with a $3,000 fine. He was also struck off the rolls. It is the duty of every advocate and solicitor regardless of position to uphold the integrity of the judicial process. When an advocate and solicitor intentionally abets a client from delaying the judicial process, which very process it is his bounden duty to uphold, it shows an extreme defect of character

Ruling: Struck off the rolls

Reasoning: Duty to uphold integrity of judicial process; intentionally abetting client to delay judicial process shows extreme defect of character

What this case tells us: Assisting clients to avoid court proceedings through deception is serious misconduct

3. LSS v Wee Wei Fen
CONDUCT: Forgery of Court documents
FACTS: Lawyer failed to take immediate action to comply with her client's instructions for nearly 4 months and she forged an order of Court to lull the client into believing that they had the necessary legal capacity to carry out certain acts when it was not the case
RULING: Disciplinary action
REASONING: Forged order to make client believe they had legal capacity when they didn't
WHAT THIS CASE TELLS US: Forging court documents to deceive clients is serious misconduct
4. Tan Ng Kuang Nicky v Metax Eco Solutions Pte Ltd
CONDUCT: Misleading Court as to status of matter
FACTS: Lawyers from both sides of the appeal had concluded a settlement but continued to allow the appeal to continue as if the issue was still live. A court in Singapore will not answer hypothetical questions or opine on an academic point merely because a party to the proceedings would like the Court to set down the law on the point
RULING: Serious breach of duties to court
REASONING: Deliberately misled court by not apprising court of true state of affairs
WHAT THIS CASE TELLS US: Lawyers must inform Court when matters are settled or no longer live
5. Loh Der Ming Andrew v Koh Tien Hua
CONDUCT: Misleading Court about client instructions
FACTS: Lawyer mislead the Court on whether he had received client's instructions pertaining to a divorce matter and whether he had communicated his concerns and case strategy to the client
RULING: Disciplinary action
REASONING: Misleading conduct in court proceedings
WHAT THIS CASE TELLS US: Lawyers must be truthful about client instructions and communications

Rule 10: Responsibility for Client's Conduct

Foundation: Rule 10 Overview and Principles

When Rule 10 applies: A legal practitioner is acting for a client in any matter

What this covers: All client representation, not just court proceedings

Underlying Principles of Rule 10

Rule 10(1) establishes 3 fundamental principles:

Rule 10(1) Fundamental Principles

  • Prevent Client Misconduct (a): Must prevent client from misleading Court or acting improperly
  • Exercise Professional Judgment (b): Must exercise judgment over advice given and documents drafted
  • Avoid Unlawful Conduct (c): Must not engage in unlawful, unethical or improper conduct

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 10 builds on Rule 9's paramount duty to Court by specifically addressing how lawyers must manage their clients' conduct. While Rule 9 focuses on the lawyer's own conduct in court, Rule 10 addresses the lawyer's responsibility to control and guide client behavior to ensure it doesn't compromise the administration of justice.

Specific Duties Under Rule 10

(A) Duty to Inform Client of Client's Duties to the Court - Rule 10(2)

When this applies: When client is a party to proceedings before court or tribunal

What this requires: Inform client of their responsibilities to court and other parties

Client Duties to Inform About

  • Be truthful to Court (a): Duty to be truthful towards court/tribunal
  • Comply with legal requirements (b): Duty to comply with every legal requirement concerning conduct and presentation of case

(B) Duty to Prevent Client from Suppressing Evidence and Giving False Evidence - Rule 10(3)

When this applies: To the extent that legal practitioner is able

What this prohibits: Must prevent client from, must not be party to, and must not assist client in:

  • Suppressing evidence (a): Must prevent client from suppressing evidence
  • Giving false evidence (b): Must prevent client from giving false evidence or information to Court

When Can a Lawyer Properly Disbelieve Client?

Standards for Disbelieving Client

  • Personal knowledge: Lawyer has personal knowledge that instructions are false
  • Inherently incredible: Client's statements are inherently incredible or logically impossible
  • Incontrovertible evidence: Instructions conflict with incontrovertible evidence or documents

Case Law - When to Disbelieve Client

Wee Soon Kim Anthony v LSS

SITUATION: Lawyer questioning whether to believe client's instructions

RULING: Lawyer should not disbelieve client's instructions unless:

  • He himself has personal knowledge of the matter
  • His client's statements are inherently incredible or logically impossible

WHAT THIS CASE TELLS US: Lawyers should generally trust client instructions

Bachoo Mohan Singh v PP

SITUATION: Conflicting evidence between client and opposing party

RULING: Lawyers should be allowed to act on their client's instructions even in the face of conflicting evidence from the opposing party and should only refuse when the instructions fly in the face of incontrovertible evidence or documents

REASONING:

  • Unless lawyer has personal knowledge that the instructions are false
  • Or if the instructions are inherently incredible or logically impossible
  • Lawyers are not fact-finders and should not act as a pre-trial sieve for their own client

(C) Duty to Supervise Disclosure Process

When this applies: When client has discovery/disclosure obligations

What this requires: Active supervision of disclosure process, not just informing client

Teo Wai Cheong v Credit Industriel et commercial

SITUATION: Bank failed to disclose documents in discovery

FACTS: Bank failed to disclose documents. Court commented that solicitors for the bank may not have taken all the steps they ought to have in discharging their duty in disclosure. Solicitors' emails to the bank merely informed it of the provisions regarding discovery, which is insufficient to discharge the solicitors' duty in discovery.

RULING: Lawyers have duty to Court to properly explain discovery obligations and supervise disclosure process

REASONING:

  • Lawyers have a duty to the Court to properly explain to their clients what the discovery obligations are
  • Lawyers also have a duty to the court to be involved in and to supervise the disclosure process
  • This duty is more onerous than simply informing the client of the provisions governing discovery

(D) Client Gives False Evidence - Lawyer's Options - Rule 10(4)

When this applies: When lawyer knows client is about to give or has given false evidence to Court

What this requires: Lawyer must choose between two options:

  • Option 1: Cease acting - Lawyer must cease to act for client
  • Option 2: Continue but don't perpetuate - If continuing, conduct case in manner that does not perpetuate falsehood

(E) Advice Sought for Dishonest, Fraudulent or Unlawful Purpose - Rule 10(5)

When this applies: When lawyer knows or has reasonable grounds to believe advice is sought for unlawful purpose

What this prohibits: Rendering advice for dishonest, fraudulent or unlawful purposes

LSS v Leong Pek Gan

SITUATION: Lawyer provided advice for unlicensed moneylending transaction

FACTS: Lawyer acted for the parties on both sides of an unlicensed moneylending transaction and preferred the moneylender's interests in the process. Lawyer had reasonable grounds to believe that the transaction involved unlicensed moneylending as several aspects of the transaction were highly unusual.

RULING: Lawyer had reasonable grounds to believe advice was sought for unlawful purpose

REASONING:

  • Step 1: Court must assume the position of the actual lawyer involved including his knowledge and experience
  • Step 2: Court must assess whether an objective reasonable person from the position of the actual lawyer and from the facts known to the actual lawyer would know that the advice was being sought for an unlawful purpose

(F) Duty to Prevent Impropriety of Client - Rule 10(6)

When this applies: When lawyer knows client is engaging in improper conduct

What this prohibits: Knowingly assisting or permitting client to:

  • Mislead Court (a): Must not assist client to mislead Court or tribunal
  • Do anything dishonest (b): Must not assist client to do anything lawyer considers dishonest

Narindar Singh s/o Malagar Singh v PP

SITUATION: Lawyer assisted client in bribery scheme

FACTS: Lawyer acted in conjunction with his client to corruptly solicit for his client's family a gratification of 100k from the family of his counterpart in exchange for the client exonerating the counterpart via the client's signed confession. Lawyer assisted client in getting a bribe in return for a confession.

RULING: Lawyer convicted and struck off

REASONING: As a senior member of the Bar and a former police officer, the court held that the lawyer should have been all the more keenly aware of the need to guard against any abuse of the justice system. His conduct was shocking and reprehensible.

Practical Guidance

Situation 1: Client gives instructions that seem false

  • Applicable Rule: Rule 10(3), Wee Soon Kim Anthony v LSS
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Does lawyer have personal knowledge that instructions are false?
    • Are client's statements inherently incredible or logically impossible?
    • Do instructions conflict with incontrovertible evidence?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • High threshold for disbelieving client
    • Lawyers are not fact-finders
    • Generally trust client instructions

Situation 2: Client wants to suppress evidence

  • Applicable Rule: Rule 10(3)(a), LSS v de Souza Christopher James
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Does lawyer have intention to assist suppression?
    • Is evidence objectively suppressed?
    • Can lawyer prevent client from suppressing?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • Must prove intent to suppress
    • Objective construction of documents matters
    • Duty only to extent lawyer is able

Situation 3: Client gives false evidence to Court

  • Applicable Rule: Rule 10(4)
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Does lawyer know evidence is false?
    • Can lawyer continue without perpetuating falsehood?
    • Is withdrawal from case appropriate?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • Two options: cease acting OR continue without perpetuating
    • Cannot rely on false evidence if continuing
    • Must conduct case without falsehood

Exam Application Framework

Step-by-Step Approach for Exam Questions

Step 1: Identify the Situation
Ask yourself: Is this about client conduct or lawyer conduct? What type of client behavior is involved? Does Rule 10 apply to this situation? What are the specific facts?
Step 2: Identify Applicable Rules
Ask yourself: Which specific subsection of Rule 10 applies? Are there any exceptions or qualifications? What is the standard required? How does this connect to Rule 9?
Step 3: Apply Case Law
Ask yourself: Which cases are most similar? What was the ruling in those cases? What was the reasoning? How does it apply to this situation?
Step 4: Reach Conclusion
Ask yourself: Is there a breach of Rule 10? What are the consequences? Are there any mitigating factors? What should the lawyer do?

Key Phrases for Exam Answers

• "Rule 10(1) establishes that lawyers have responsibility for client conduct..." • "Under Rule 10(3), lawyers must prevent clients from..." • "In [Case Name], the Court held that..." • "The reasoning was that..." • "The standard requires..." • "Applying this principle to the present case..." • "Therefore, there is/is not a breach of Rule 10..."

What this covers: All client representation, not just court proceedings

Underlying Principles of Rule 10

Rule 10(1) establishes 3 fundamental principles:

Rule 10(1) Fundamental Principles

PrincipleRule 10(1) ProvisionWhat This Means
1. Prevent Client Misconduct(a)Must prevent client from misleading Court or acting improperly
2. Exercise Professional Judgment(b)Must exercise judgment over advice given and documents drafted
3. Avoid Unlawful Conduct(c)Must not engage in unlawful, unethical or improper conduct

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 10 builds on Rule 9's paramount duty to Court by specifically addressing how lawyers must manage their clients' conduct. While Rule 9 focuses on the lawyer's own conduct in court, Rule 10 addresses the lawyer's responsibility to control and guide client behavior to ensure it doesn't compromise the administration of justice.

Specific Duties Under Rule 10

(A) Duty to Inform Client of Client's Duties to the Court - Rule 10(2)

When this applies: When client is a party to proceedings before court or tribunal

What this requires: Inform client of their responsibilities to court and other parties

Client Duties to Inform About

EntryClient DutyRule 10(2) Provision
(i)Be truthful to Court(a) - Duty to be truthful towards court/tribunal
(ii)Comply with legal requirements(b) - Duty to comply with every legal requirement concerning conduct and presentation of case

What This Means

Lawyers must educate their clients about:

  • The importance of truthfulness in court proceedings
  • All procedural and substantive legal requirements
  • The client's role in the administration of justice

(B) Duty to Prevent Client from Suppressing Evidence and Giving False Evidence - Rule 10(3)

When this applies: To the extent that legal practitioner is able

What this prohibits: Must prevent client from, must not be party to, and must not assist client in:

Prohibited Client Conduct

EntryProhibited ConductRule 10(3) Provision
(i)Suppressing evidence(a) - Must prevent client from suppressing evidence
(ii)Giving false evidence(b) - Must prevent client from giving false evidence or information to Court

When Can a Lawyer Properly Disbelieve Client?

Standards for Disbelieving Client

EntryStandardWhen Lawyer Can Disbelieve
(i)Personal knowledgeLawyer has personal knowledge that instructions are false
(ii)Inherently incredibleClient's statements are inherently incredible or logically impossible
(iii)Incontrovertible evidenceInstructions conflict with incontrovertible evidence or documents

Wee Soon Kim Anthony v LSS

Situation: Lawyer questioning whether to believe client's instructions

Ruling: Lawyer should not disbelieve client's instructions unless:

  • He himself has personal knowledge of the matter
  • His client's statements are inherently incredible or logically impossible

Key reasoning: High threshold for disbelieving client; requires personal knowledge or inherent incredibility

Bachoo Mohan Singh v PP

Situation: Conflicting evidence between client and opposing party

Ruling: Lawyers should be allowed to act on their client's instructions even in the face of conflicting evidence from the opposing party and should only refuse when the instructions fly in the face of incontrovertible evidence or documents

Key reasoning: Lawyers are not fact-finders; high threshold for refusing instructions

Integrated Practical Guidance

Situation 1: Client gives instructions that seem false

  • Applicable Rule: Rule 10(3), Wee Soon Kim Anthony v LSS
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Does lawyer have personal knowledge that instructions are false?
    • Are client's statements inherently incredible or logically impossible?
    • Do instructions conflict with incontrovertible evidence?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • High threshold for disbelieving client
    • Lawyers are not fact-finders
    • Generally trust client instructions

Situation 2: Client gives false evidence to Court

  • Applicable Rule: Rule 10(4)
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Does lawyer know evidence is false?
    • Can lawyer continue without perpetuating falsehood?
    • Is withdrawal from case appropriate?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • Two options: cease acting OR continue without perpetuating
    • Cannot rely on false evidence if continuing
    • Must conduct case without falsehood

Rule 11: Conflict of Interest in Proceedings before Court or Tribunal

When Rule 11 Applies

Rule 11 applies when: A legal practitioner is appearing before a Court or tribunal

What this covers: Conflicts that could affect professional independence or impartial administration of justice

Underlying Principles of Rule 11

Rule 11(1) establishes the fundamental principle:

Full Rule 11(1)

"A legal practitioner's duty to advance the interests of the legal practitioner's client and to present the client's best possible case, is subject to the legal practitioner's duties as an officer of the Court and to assist in the administration of justice."

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 11 builds on Rules 9 and 10 by addressing situations where the lawyer's personal interests or relationships might compromise their ability to serve the administration of justice. While Rules 9 and 10 focus on the lawyer's conduct and client management, Rule 11 addresses structural conflicts that could undermine the lawyer's professional independence.

Specific Duties Under Rule 11

(A) Duty Not to Appear Before Court If Lawyer Is In Conflict of Interest - Rule 11(2)

When this applies: When appearing before Court or tribunal

What this prohibits: Two types of conflicts

Types of Conflicts Under Rule 11(2)

EntryType of ConflictRule 11(2) ProvisionWhat This Means
(i)Professional Independence(a)Cannot maintain independence due to relationship with client
(ii)Impartial Administration(b)Justice might be prejudiced due to relationship with Court

What This Means

  • Type (i): Commercial, family, personal relationships that compromise independence
  • Type (ii): Relationships with Court/tribunal members that could prejudice justice

(B) Lawyer Cannot Be Witness and Act for Party in Same Case - Rule 11(3)

When this applies: When lawyer will be required to give evidence material to contested issue

What this requires: Lawyer must not act for any party in that case

Lawyer-Witness Conflict Rules

EntrySituationRule 11(3) ProvisionAction Required
(i)Lawyer will be material witness(a)(i)Must not accept instructions from any party
(ii)Lawyer already acting for party(a)(ii)Must discharge himself or apply to be discharged
(iii)Another lawyer in same firm(b)May continue unless prejudices administration of justice

Then Khek Khoon v Arjun Permanand Samtani

Situation: Solicitor's own interest conflicts with client's interests

Ruling: Solicitor's own interest cannot conflict with the interests of the client and the court

Reasoning:

  • Protection of client and the client must be the aggrieved party when his lawyer breaches this duty
  • Implication: This rule is not supposed to be invoked by the opposing counsel
  • E.g. of Conflict: Where an uninformed or disadvantaged client has been grossly overcharged by his lawyer => Lawyer cannot represent the client in proceedings brought against himself for fees charged

What this case tells us: Rule 11 is for protection of client, not opposing counsel

Key reasoning: Client must be aggrieved party; rule protects client from lawyer's conflicting interests

Ho Kon Kim v Betsy Lim Gek Kim

Situation: Same firm has both material witness and counsel

Facts:

  • Lawyer firm previously acted for the Plaintiff in the sale of a property and mortgage to a bank
  • Dispute broke out between the Plaintiff and the Defendant who is a party in the transaction
  • Conveyancing partner of the firm knew that he would be a material witness in the proceedings against the Defendant
  • Litigation partner of the firm continued to act for the Plaintiff in the proceedings

Ruling: Firm should have ceased acting for the Plaintiff immediately

Reasoning:

  • Conflict because both material witness in the proceedings and the counsel are from the same firm
  • High Court observed that the firm should have ceased acting for the Plaintiff immediately
  • SGCA commented that both lawyers should have discharged themselves from acting for Plaintiff and advise her to seek independent legal advice

What this case tells us: Same firm cannot have both witness and counsel in same case

Key reasoning: Both lawyers had personal interest; firm should have ceased acting entirely

Integrated Practical Guidance

Situation 1: Lawyer has personal relationship with client

  • Applicable Rule: Rule 11(2)(a)
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Is relationship commercial, family, or personal?
    • Would relationship compromise professional independence?
    • Can lawyer maintain objectivity?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • Must not appear if independence compromised
    • Relationship must not affect professional judgment

Situation 2: Lawyer has relationship with Court/tribunal member

  • Applicable Rule: Rule 11(2)(b)
  • Factors to Consider:
    • What is the nature of relationship?
    • Could it prejudice impartial administration of justice?
    • Would it create appearance of bias?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • Must not appear if justice might be prejudiced
    • Appearance of bias is sufficient

Situation 3: Lawyer will be material witness in case

  • Applicable Rule: Rule 11(3)(a)
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Will evidence be material to contested issue?
    • Is lawyer already acting for party?
    • Can another lawyer in firm continue?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • Must not accept instructions from any party
    • Must discharge if already acting
    • Another lawyer may continue unless prejudices justice

Rule 12: Communications and Dealings with Witnesses

When Rule 12 Applies

Rule 12 applies when: A legal practitioner is dealing with any witness

What this covers: All communications and dealings with witnesses in proceedings

Underlying Principles of Rule 12

Rule 12(1) establishes 2 fundamental principles:

Full Rule 12(1)

"A legal practitioner must ensure that he acts in a manner consistent with the administration of justice when dealing with any witness, regardless of the effect or potential effect of the evidence given or to be given by that witness."

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 12 complements Rules 9, 10, and 11 by specifically addressing how lawyers must interact with witnesses to ensure the integrity of the evidence-gathering process. This rule ensures that witness testimony remains reliable and that the administration of justice is not compromised by improper witness handling.

Rule 13: Respect for Court or Tribunal and Related Responsibilities

When Rule 13 Applies

Rule 13 applies when: A legal practitioner is appearing before or dealing with a Court or tribunal

What this covers: Respectful conduct, undertakings, and related responsibilities

Underlying Principles of Rule 13

Rule 13(1) establishes 2 fundamental principles:

Full Rule 13(1)

"A legal practitioner must present a case, and behave, before a Court or tribunal in a manner which is respectful of the Court or tribunal."

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 13 completes the framework of Rules 9-12 by ensuring that lawyers maintain proper respect for the judicial system. While Rules 9-12 focus on substantive conduct, Rule 13 addresses the tone and manner of interaction with the Court, ensuring that the administration of justice is conducted with appropriate dignity and respect.

Key Duties Under Rule 13

(A) Duty to Be Respectful to Court - Rule 13(2)

When this applies: When appearing before Court or tribunal

What this requires: Always respectful conduct and demeanor

What This Means

  • Proper address (Your Honor, Judge, etc.)
  • Appropriate dress and demeanor
  • Respectful language and conduct
  • Maintaining dignity of Court

(B) Duty to Honor All Undertakings Given to Court - Rule 13(4)

When this applies: When giving undertakings to Court

What this requires: Strict compliance with all undertakings

What This Means

  • Undertakings are binding promises to Court
  • Must be fulfilled exactly as given
  • Failure to honor undertaking is serious misconduct

Law Society v Seow Francis T

Situation: Lawyer failed to honor undertaking given to Attorney General

Facts:

  • Police wanted to come to lawyer's firm to seize relevant files
  • Lawyer gave an undertaking to the AG to hand over all relevant files
  • Based on the undertaking, police did not search the firm for the files

Ruling: Lawyer suspended for 1 year

Reasoning: Turns out, lawyer did not direct a search for relevant files and in the end, he failed to hand over some of the relevant files. Lawyer failed to do what was necessary to fulfil his undertaking

What this case tells us: Undertakings must be fulfilled completely

Key reasoning: Failure to take necessary steps to fulfill undertaking is misconduct

Integrated Practical Guidance

Situation 1: Giving undertaking to Court

  • Applicable Rule: Rule 13(4), 13(5)
  • Factors to Consider:
    • Is undertaking necessary?
    • Can lawyer fulfill undertaking?
    • Is undertaking clear and specific?
  • Exceptions/Qualifications:
    • Must honor all undertakings given
    • Only give necessary and fulfillable undertakings
    • Undertakings are binding promises

Rules 14, 15, 7: Criminal Proceedings & Lawyer Relationships

Overview

This section covers three important rules: Rule 14 (Criminal Defense), Rule 15 (Criminal Prosecution), and Rule 7 (Professional Relationships)

I. Rule 14: Conducting Defence in Criminal Proceedings

When Rule 14 Applies

Rule 14 applies when: A legal practitioner represents an accused person in criminal proceedings

What this covers: All aspects of criminal defense representation

Underlying Principles of Rule 14

Rule 14(1) establishes 2 fundamental principles:

Full Rule 14(1)

"A legal practitioner who represents an accused person in any criminal proceedings is under a fundamental duty to assist in the administration of justice."

Full Rule 14(1)(b)

"A legal practitioner who represents an accused person in any criminal proceedings must present the accused person's case and behave in a manner which is consistent with the aim of PCR, and must comply with the constitutional, evidential and procedural rules which operate in a criminal trial."

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 14 builds on Rules 9-13 by specifically addressing the unique challenges of criminal defense work. While the general rules apply, criminal defense has special considerations around client confessions, bail, and the balance between zealous advocacy and the administration of justice.

Defense Lawyer's Duty to Pursue Every Reasonable Defense - Rule 14(2)

Full Rule 14(2)

"A legal practitioner who represents an accused person in any criminal proceedings must pursue every reasonable defense and raise every favorable factor on behalf of the accused person in accordance with law."

When This Applies

  • When this applies: When representing accused person in criminal proceedings
  • What this requires: Pursue every reasonable defense and raise every favorable factor

Important Qualification

Note that this is not an unqualified duty – every defense must be reasonable, and every factor raised must be in accordance with law.

Case Law - Reasonable Defense Standard

Iskandar bin Rahmat v LSS

SITUATION: No ethical breach by Defense Lawyers who reasonably accepted doctor's professional assessment that accused could not use defense of diminished responsibility

FACTS:

  • Client alleged that lawyers lacked diligence, failed to follow instructions and failed to advance his case using all legal means and all reasonable defenses as they had failed to advance the defense of diminished responsibility
  • Client was unhappy as the defense team had not prolonged his trial by use of all means

RULING: No ethical breach committed by defense lawyers

REASONING:

  • Client's instructions to defense lawyers did not reveal facts giving rise to a defense of diminished responsibility
  • Defense lawyers could reasonably accept doctor's professional assessment on the matter
  • At each point, the defense lawyers had rendered advice and sought the relevant instructions
  • The exhibits, witnesses and evidence sought by the client were not relevant to his defense
  • Lawyers are right in not prolonging trial as they owe a higher allegiance to the cause of truth and justice and are not mere mouthpieces of the client

WHAT THIS CASE TELLS US: Defense counsel must pursue reasonable defenses, not all possible defenses

KEY REASONING: Defense counsel's role is to take instructions and consider what defenses are reasonable and supported by facts; lawyers owe allegiance to truth and justice, not just client

Defense Lawyer's Duty Not to Pursue Certain Acts - Rule 14(3)

Full Rule 14(3)

"A legal practitioner who represents an accused person:

  • (a) Must not provide any surety or bail for accused person
  • (b) Must not express legal practitioner's opinion as to whether the accused person is guilty or allow any such opinion to affect the legal practitioner's professional assessment of the facts or the law, the legal practitioner's conduct of criminal proceedings or the legal practitioner's duty to the accused person or court
  • (c) Must not be absent from a trial or hearing without reasonable grounds
  • (d) Must, if absent from a trial or hearing:
    • (i) Communicate the grounds for the legal practitioner's absence to the accused person before the trial or hearing; and
    • (ii) Make reasonable efforts to arrange for another legal practitioner to take over the conduct of the trial or hearing; and
  • (e) Must continue to reasonably assist the accused person after the accused person is convicted and sentenced."

Prohibited Acts Under Rule 14(3)

  • Provide bail/surety (a): Creates personal interest conflicting with client duties
  • Express opinion on guilt (b): Must maintain professional objectivity
  • Absent without grounds (c): Must be present for client's defense
  • Fail to arrange substitute (d): Must ensure client has representation
  • Abandon after conviction (e): Must continue assistance post-conviction

Rationale for Bail Rule

  • Bail – money put at risk personally by a surety to ensure attendance of accused in future court proceedings
  • Putting up bail shows that lawyer has a personal interest in the release of the client beyond the scope of representation
  • Creates conflict between lawyer's personal financial interest and professional duties

II. Rule 15: Conducting the Prosecution

When Rule 15 Applies

Rule 15 applies when: A legal practitioner represents the State in criminal proceedings as a prosecutor

What this covers: All aspects of criminal prosecution representation

Underlying Principles of Rule 15

Rule 15(1) Fundamental Principle

"A legal practitioner who represents the State in any criminal proceedings as a prosecutor is under a fundamental duty to assist in the administration of justice."

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 15 builds on Rules 9-14 by specifically addressing the unique role of prosecutors. While defense counsel advocates for their client, prosecutors represent the public interest and have heightened duties to ensure fairness and justice.

Prosecutor's Duty to be Fair and Impartial - Rule 15(2)

Full Rule 15(2)

"A legal practitioner who represents the State in any criminal proceedings as a prosecutor must:

  • (a) Present the case for the State fairly and impartially;
  • (b) Ensure that the accused person is accorded a fair trial; and
  • (c) Assist the Court in arriving at the truth and in the impartial administration of justice."

What This Means

  • Fair presentation: Present evidence objectively, not just to win
  • Fair trial: Ensure accused gets proper defense opportunities
  • Assist truth-finding: Help court reach correct verdict

III. Rule 7: Relationship with Other Legal Practitioners

When Rule 7 Applies

Rule 7 applies when: A legal practitioner deals with another legal practitioner

What this covers: Professional relationships and interactions between lawyers

Underlying Principles of Rule 7

Rule 7(1) Fundamental Principle

"A legal practitioner must relate to another legal practitioner in a manner which promotes the administration of justice."

Duty to Relate Professionally - Rule 7(2)

Full Rule 7(2)

"A legal practitioner must relate to another legal practitioner:

  • (a) With courtesy and respect;
  • (b) In a manner which promotes the administration of justice; and
  • (c) In accordance with the standards of professional conduct expected of a legal practitioner."

What This Means

  • Courtesy and respect: Professional demeanor in all interactions
  • Promote justice: Interactions should serve broader justice goals
  • Professional standards: Maintain expected professional conduct

Practical Guidance

These three rules work together to ensure proper conduct in criminal proceedings and professional relationships. Defense counsel must zealously but reasonably advocate for clients, prosecutors must fairly seek justice, and all lawyers must treat each other with professional courtesy.

Rule 15: Conducting the Prosecution

When Rule 15 Applies

Rule 15 applies when: A legal practitioner represents the State in criminal proceedings as a prosecutor

What this covers: All aspects of criminal prosecution representation

Underlying Principles of Rule 15

Rule 15(1) Fundamental Principle

"A legal practitioner who represents the State in any criminal proceedings as a prosecutor is under a fundamental duty to assist in the administration of justice."

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 15 builds on Rules 9-14 by specifically addressing the unique role of prosecutors. While defense counsel advocates for their client, prosecutors represent the public interest and have heightened duties to ensure fairness and justice.

Prosecutor's Duty to be Fair and Impartial - Rule 15(2)

Full Rule 15(2)

"A legal practitioner who represents the State in any criminal proceedings as a prosecutor must:

  • (a) Present the case for the State fairly and impartially;
  • (b) Ensure that the accused person is accorded a fair trial; and
  • (c) Assist the Court in arriving at the truth and in the impartial administration of justice."

What This Means

  • Fair presentation: Present evidence objectively, not just to win
  • Fair trial: Ensure accused gets proper defense opportunities
  • Assist truth-finding: Help court reach correct verdict

Prosecutor's Duty to Disclose - Rule 15(3)

Full Rule 15(3)

"A legal practitioner who represents the State in any criminal proceedings as a prosecutor must ensure that all material which ought to be disclosed to the accused person is disclosed in a timely manner."

Disclosure Obligations

  • All material evidence: Must disclose evidence favorable to defense
  • Timely disclosure: Must disclose in time for defense to use effectively
  • Proactive duty: Must actively ensure disclosure happens

Prosecutor's Duty Not to Pursue Certain Acts - Rule 15(4)

Full Rule 15(4)

"A legal practitioner who represents the State in any criminal proceedings as a prosecutor:

  • (a) Must not express the legal practitioner's opinion as to whether the accused person is guilty;
  • (b) Must not be absent from a trial or hearing without reasonable grounds;
  • (c) Must, if absent from a trial or hearing, make reasonable efforts to arrange for another legal practitioner to take over the conduct of the trial or hearing."

Prohibited Acts

  • No opinion on guilt: Must maintain objectivity
  • Must be present: Cannot be absent without grounds
  • Arrange substitute: Must ensure proceedings continue

Case Law - Prosecutorial Conduct

PP v Lim Boon Hiong

SITUATION: Prosecutor's conduct during trial

PRINCIPLE: Prosecutors must be fair and assist in administration of justice

REASONING: Prosecutor represents public interest, not just winning cases

Practical Guidance

Key Differences from Defense Counsel

  • Client: Prosecutor serves public interest, not individual client
  • Goal: Justice and truth, not just conviction
  • Disclosure: Must disclose favorable evidence to defense
  • Fairness: Must ensure accused gets fair trial

Rule 7: Relationship with Other Legal Practitioners

When Rule 7 Applies

Rule 7 applies when: A legal practitioner deals with another legal practitioner

What this covers: Professional relationships and interactions between lawyers

Underlying Principles of Rule 7

Rule 7(1) Fundamental Principle

"A legal practitioner must relate to another legal practitioner in a manner which promotes the administration of justice."

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 7 builds on the general principles of professional conduct by specifically addressing how lawyers should interact with each other. This ensures the legal profession maintains collegiality while serving the administration of justice.

Duty to Relate Professionally - Rule 7(2)

Full Rule 7(2)

"A legal practitioner must relate to another legal practitioner:

  • (a) With courtesy and respect;
  • (b) In a manner which promotes the administration of justice; and
  • (c) In accordance with the standards of professional conduct expected of a legal practitioner."

What This Means

  • Courtesy and respect: Professional demeanor in all interactions
  • Promote justice: Interactions should serve broader justice goals
  • Professional standards: Maintain expected professional conduct

Duty Not to Take Unfair Advantage - Rule 7(3)

Full Rule 7(3)

"A legal practitioner must not take unfair advantage of another legal practitioner."

Examples of Unfair Advantage

  • Misleading about deadlines: Providing false information about court dates
  • Bad faith negotiations: Negotiating without genuine intent to settle
  • Procedural tricks: Using technicalities to disadvantage opposing counsel
  • Breach of professional courtesy: Violating accepted professional norms

Duty to Honor Undertakings - Rule 7(4)

Full Rule 7(4)

"A legal practitioner must honor any undertaking given to another legal practitioner."

What This Means

  • Binding commitment: Undertakings create binding obligations
  • Professional trust: Enables lawyers to trust each other's word
  • System efficiency: Reduces need for formal documentation

Case Law - Professional Relationships

Public Trustee v By Products Traders Pte Ltd

PRINCIPLE: Lawyers should not take unfair advantage of one another

REASONING: Professional courtesy ensures efficient administration of justice

QUOTE: "An advocate should be fearless in carrying out the interests of his client, but the arms which he wields are to be the arms of the warrior and not of the assassin."

Practical Guidance

Professional Courtesy Examples

  • Scheduling: Reasonable accommodation for opposing counsel's schedule
  • Extensions: Reasonable requests for time extensions
  • Communications: Prompt and honest responses
  • Undertakings: Clear and honored commitments

Balance Required

Rule 7 requires lawyers to balance zealous advocacy for their clients with professional courtesy to opposing counsel. The goal is vigorous but fair representation that serves the administration of justice.

Rule 28: Entering Default Judgment

When Rule 28 Applies

Rule 28 applies when: A legal practitioner wants to enter default judgment against a party represented by another lawyer

What this covers: Professional courtesy in default judgment procedures

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 28 builds on the general principle of professional courtesy by specifically addressing default judgment procedures. It ensures lawyers don't take unfair advantage of each other's oversight while maintaining the efficiency of court proceedings.

Duty to Observe 2-Day Notice Requirement - Rule 28(1)

Full Rule 28(1)

"A legal practitioner (A) must not enter a default judgment under any provision of Rules of Court against a party who is represented by another legal practitioner (B) unless:

  • (a) A has given B written notice of A's intention to enter default judgement; AND
  • (b) At least 2 working days have elapsed after notice is given to B."

What This Means

  • Written notice: Must give written notice to opposing counsel
  • 2 working days: Must wait at least 2 working days after notice
  • Fair opportunity: Ensures fair opportunity to respond
  • Professional courtesy: Prevents unfair advantage taking

Notice Timing Rules - Rule 28(2)

Full Rule 28(2)

"Any notice under Rule 28(1) that is given on a working day after 4pm or on a day other than a working day is to be treated as given on the next working day."

What This Means

  • After 4pm: Notice treated as given on next working day
  • Non-working days: Notice treated as given on next working day
  • Fair timing: Ensures reasonable time to respond

Definition of Working Day - Rule 28(4)

Full Rule 28(4)

"'Working day' means any day other than a Saturday, Sunday or public holiday."

Interaction with ROC Deadlines - Rule 28(3)

Full Rule 28(3)

"To avoid doubt:

  • (a) This rule does not extend the time stipulated by an order of Court or by any provision of the Rules of Court 2021 for taking any action or step; and
  • (b) A legal practitioner need not give any notice under Para (1) before taking any action or step on a failure to comply with an order of Court within the time stipulated by the order of Court."

What This Means

  • ROC deadlines prevail: Rule 28 does not extend ROC deadlines
  • Court orders: No notice required for failure to comply with court orders
  • Balance: Professional courtesy balanced with procedural requirements

Case Law - Professional Courtesy

Public Trustee v By Products Traders Pte Ltd

PRINCIPLE: Lawyers should not take unfair advantage of one another

REASONING: Rule 28(1) is a rule of professional courtesy and fairness intended to ensure that lawyers do not take unfair advantage of the oversight of another

QUOTE: "An advocate should be fearless in carrying out the interests of his client, but the arms which he wields are to be the arms of the warrior and not of the assassin. It is his duty to strive to accomplish the interests of his clients per fas and not per nefas"

Practical Guidance

Best Practices

  • Clear notice: Provide clear written notice of intention
  • Proper timing: Ensure notice given during working hours
  • Allow response time: Give reasonable opportunity to respond
  • Check deadlines: Ensure compliance with ROC requirements

Rule 29: Allegations Against Another Legal Practitioner

When Rule 29 Applies

Rule 29 applies when: A legal practitioner makes allegations against another legal practitioner

What this covers: Professional standards for making allegations against colleagues

Duty to Make Allegations Properly - Rule 29(1)

Full Rule 29(1)

"A legal practitioner must not make any allegation against another legal practitioner unless:

  • (a) The allegation is made in good faith;
  • (b) The allegation is supported by reasonable grounds; and
  • (c) The allegation is necessary for the proper conduct of the legal practitioner's case."

What This Means

  • Good faith: Genuine belief in the allegation
  • Reasonable grounds: Factual basis for the allegation
  • Necessary: Required for proper conduct of case

Practical Guidance

Before Making Allegations

  • Assess necessity: Is allegation truly necessary for your case?
  • Check evidence: Do you have reasonable grounds?
  • Consider impact: Will allegation serve administration of justice?
  • Professional courtesy: Consider speaking to colleague first if appropriate

Rule 30: Communication with Court

When Rule 30 Applies

Rule 30 applies when: A legal practitioner communicates with the Court

What this covers: Proper procedures for court communications

Duty to Copy Opposing Counsel - Rule 30(1)

Full Rule 30(1)

"A legal practitioner must not communicate with the Court about any matter relating to proceedings before the Court unless:

  • (a) All parties to the proceedings are present; or
  • (b) The legal practitioner has given all other parties reasonable notice of the communication and a reasonable opportunity to be present."

What This Means

  • No ex parte communications: Cannot communicate with court without other parties
  • Notice required: Must give reasonable notice to other parties
  • Opportunity to be present: Other parties must have chance to participate

Exceptions

When Notice Not Required

  • Administrative matters: Purely procedural communications
  • Emergency applications: Where urgency prevents notice
  • Court-initiated: Where court requests information

Practical Guidance

Best Practices

  • Copy all parties: Include all parties in court communications
  • Reasonable notice: Give adequate time for response
  • Document communications: Keep records of all court communications
  • Transparency: Maintain open communication process

Rule 31: Communication with Another Legal Practitioner

When Rule 31 Applies

Rule 31 applies when: A legal practitioner communicates with another legal practitioner

What this covers: Professional standards for lawyer-to-lawyer communications

Duty to Communicate Professionally - Rule 31(1)

Full Rule 31(1)

"A legal practitioner must communicate with another legal practitioner:

  • (a) In a professional manner;
  • (b) With courtesy and respect; and
  • (c) In accordance with the standards of professional conduct expected of a legal practitioner."

What This Means

  • Professional manner: Maintain professional standards in all communications
  • Courtesy and respect: Treat colleagues with respect
  • Professional standards: Meet expected conduct standards

Duty to be Truthful - Rule 31(2)

Full Rule 31(2)

"A legal practitioner must be truthful in all communications with another legal practitioner."

Practical Guidance

Professional Communication Standards

  • Honesty: Always be truthful in communications
  • Timeliness: Respond promptly to communications
  • Clarity: Communicate clearly and unambiguously
  • Respect: Maintain professional courtesy even in disagreement

Rule 8: Conduct in Relation to Other Persons

When Rule 8 Applies

Rule 8 applies when: A legal practitioner deals with any person other than clients, courts, or other legal practitioners

What this covers: Professional conduct with third parties, witnesses, and other persons

Duty to Act Professionally - Rule 8(1)

Full Rule 8(1)

"A legal practitioner must act in relation to any person (other than the legal practitioner's client, a Court or tribunal, or another legal practitioner) in a manner which promotes the administration of justice."

What This Means

  • Professional conduct: Maintain professional standards with all persons
  • Promote justice: Actions should serve administration of justice
  • Broad application: Covers witnesses, third parties, court staff, etc.

Specific Duties - Rule 8(2)

Full Rule 8(2)

"A legal practitioner must not:

  • (a) Mislead or attempt to mislead any person;
  • (b) Take unfair advantage of any person; or
  • (c) Act in a manner which is prejudicial to the administration of justice."

Prohibited Conduct

  • No misleading: Cannot mislead any person
  • No unfair advantage: Cannot take unfair advantage
  • No prejudicial conduct: Cannot act in manner prejudicial to justice

Practical Applications

Common Situations

  • Witnesses: Must not coach or mislead witnesses
  • Third parties: Must deal honestly with third parties
  • Court staff: Must be respectful and professional
  • Media: Must not prejudice proceedings through media

Rules 28-31, 8: Procedures & Professional Conduct

Overview

This section covers Rules 28-31 and Rule 8, which govern procedural requirements and professional conduct with all persons.

I. Rule 28: Entering Default Judgment

When Rule 28 Applies

Rule 28 applies when: A legal practitioner wants to enter default judgment against a party represented by another lawyer

What this covers: Professional courtesy in default judgment procedures

Connection to Bigger Picture

Rule 28 builds on the general principle of professional courtesy by specifically addressing default judgment procedures. It ensures lawyers don't take unfair advantage of each other's oversight while maintaining the efficiency of court proceedings.

Duty to Observe 2-Day Notice Requirement - Rule 28(1)

Full Rule 28(1)

"A legal practitioner (A) must not enter a default judgment under any provision of Rules of Court against a party who is represented by another legal practitioner (B) unless:

  • (a) A has given B written notice of A's intention to enter default judgement; AND
  • (b) At least 2 working days have elapsed after notice is given to B."

What This Means

  • Written notice: Must give written notice to opposing counsel
  • 2 working days: Must wait at least 2 working days after notice
  • Fair opportunity: Ensures fair opportunity to respond
  • Professional courtesy: Prevents unfair advantage taking

II. Rule 29: Allegations Against Another Legal Practitioner

When Rule 29 Applies

Rule 29 applies when: A legal practitioner makes allegations against another legal practitioner

What this covers: Professional standards for making allegations against colleagues

Duty to Make Allegations Properly - Rule 29(1)

Full Rule 29(1)

  • (a) The allegation is made in good faith;

What This Means

  • Good faith: Genuine belief in the allegation
  • Reasonable grounds: Factual basis for the allegation
  • Necessary: Required for proper conduct of case

III. Rule 30: Communication with Court

What this covers: Proper procedures for court communications

  • (a) All parties to the proceedings are present; or

What This Means

  • Opportunity to be present: Other parties must have chance to participate

IV. Rule 31: Communication with Another Legal Practitioner

When Rule 31 Applies

Rule 31 applies when: A legal practitioner communicates with another legal practitioner

What this covers: Professional standards for lawyer-to-lawyer communications

Duty to Communicate Professionally - Rule 31(1)

Full Rule 31(1)

"A legal practitioner must communicate with another legal practitioner:

  • (a) In a professional manner;
  • (b) With courtesy and respect; and
  • (c) In accordance with the standards of professional conduct expected of a legal practitioner."

Duty to be Truthful - Rule 31(2)

Full Rule 31(2)

"A legal practitioner must be truthful in all communications with another legal practitioner."

V. Rule 8: Conduct in Relation to Other Persons

When Rule 8 Applies

Rule 8 applies when: A legal practitioner deals with any person other than clients, courts, or other legal practitioners

What this covers: Professional conduct with third parties, witnesses, and other persons

Duty to Act Professionally - Rule 8(1)

Full Rule 8(1)

"A legal practitioner must act in relation to any person (other than the legal practitioner's client, a Court or tribunal, or another legal practitioner) in a manner which promotes the administration of justice."

Specific Duties - Rule 8(2)

Full Rule 8(2)

"A legal practitioner must not:

  • (a) Mislead or attempt to mislead any person;
  • (b) Take unfair advantage of any person; or
  • (c) Act in a manner which is prejudicial to the administration of justice."

Prohibited Conduct

  • No misleading: Cannot mislead any person
  • No unfair advantage: Cannot take unfair advantage
  • No prejudicial conduct: Cannot act in manner prejudicial to justice

Practical Applications

  • Witnesses: Must not coach or mislead witnesses
  • Third parties: Must deal honestly with third parties
  • Court staff: Must be respectful and professional
  • Media: Must not prejudice proceedings through media

🎯 Exam Preparation Framework

Step-by-Step Approach for Exam Questions

Step 1: Identify the Situation
Ask yourself:
  • What type of conduct is involved?
  • Who are the parties involved?
  • Is this about court proceedings, client relationships, or lawyer relationships?
Step 2: Identify Applicable Rules
Ask yourself:
  • Which specific rule and subsection applies?
  • Are there any exceptions?
  • What is the standard required?
Step 3: Apply Case Law
Ask yourself:
  • Which cases are most similar?
  • What was the ruling in those cases?
  • What was the reasoning?
  • How does it apply to this situation?
Step 4: Reach Conclusion
Ask yourself:
  • Is there a breach of the rule?
  • What are the consequences?
  • Are there any mitigating factors?
  • What should the lawyer do?

Key Phrases for Exam Answers

• "Rule [X] requires [specific requirement] before [action]" • "In [Case Name], the Court held that..." • "The reasoning was that..." • "Applying this principle to the present case..." • "Therefore, there is/is not a breach of Rule [X]..." • "The consequences would be..." • "The lawyer should/should not [action] because..."

Common Exam Scenarios

• Client confesses to defense lawyer • Lawyer wants to enter default judgment • Making allegations against another lawyer • Ex parte communication with court • Dealing with unrepresented person • Threatening criminal proceedings for civil debt • Conflict of interest in proceedings • Witness preparation vs. coaching • Undertaking to another lawyer • Personal conduct affecting professional standing
